dc:description:
*CWF19L1* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive spinocerebellar ataxia in 2014 (Burns R, et al., PMID: 25361784). The *CWF19L1* gene is thought to play a role in cell cycle control, endosomal trafficking and mRNA processing (PMID: 36357319). Autosomal recessive cerebellar ataxia due to variants in *CWF19L1* is characterized by gait, limb, and truncal ataxia, developmental delay, hypotonia, intellectual disability, and cerebellar atrophy or hypoplasia on brain imaging. Other features may be present as well and patients typically, but not always, have an early age of onset (PMID: 36453471).

Fourteen variants (4 canonical splice-site, 5 missense, 2 frameshift, 2 nonsense, 1 in-frame deletion) that have been reported in 12 probands in 9 publications (PMIDs: 25361784, 26197978, 27016154, 38681507, 36357319, 36530930, 36453471, 37752213, 33012273) are included in this curation. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity is loss of function.

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by a morpholino-mediated knockdown of *CWF19L1* in zebrafish that led to cerebellar and movement abnormalities (PMID: 25361784).

In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *CWF19L1* and autosomal recessive spinocerebellar ataxia. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Ataxia GCEP on the meeting date May 14, 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: Humans with variants in CWF19L1 have been reported to have ataxia and cerebellar atrophy. Morpholino knockdown in zebrafish lead to cerebellar and movement abnormalities, similar to humans, which was evidenced by reduced swim speed and abnormal touch-evoked escape response, altered/diminished cerebellar staining in I8E9 morphants that worsened with increasing MO concentration.
evidence.rdfs:label: Morpholino-mediated knockdown of CWF19L1

evidence.dc:description: This frameshift variant, P156Hfs*33 in exon 5/14, is absent from gnomAD v4.1.0. Down-scored for consanguinity (0.5 points) and incomplete NMD (3 points).

Western blot of patient LCL cells showed no detectable full-length CWF19L protein and no change in expression of other putative isoforms of C19L1 generated by the alternative start codons, consistent with a loss of function.

evidence.rdfs:label: Evers Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Birth weight (2,700 g, −2.3 SD), length (46 cm, −3.09 SD) and OFC (33 cm, −2.23 SD) were below the normal range. MRI at age 3 years 11 months revealed isolated cerebellar atrophy, affecting the cerebellar vermis and hemispheres. “Mental Processing Scale” score of 57 (normal range 85–115), a “Sequential Scale” score of 56 and a “Simultaneous Scale” score of 57. Cognitive deficits were obvious in the “Nonverbal Scale” (global score: 52). MRI showed thin cerebellar folia and prominent interfolial spaces
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Nine variants other variants were found but were not located within the linkage regions (Supplemental Table S1). Eight variants were non-synonymous SNVs (in the genes FLG, ZBED6, DRD1, SSH1, LPIN2, KIAA0355, BPIFB6, DLGAP4). The variant in MYO7, a gene coding for a myosin protein, was predicted to result in a loss of the stop codon. It was excluded from further considerations because it was also present in a local control in-house database [Granzow et al., 2015] and because mutations in this gene lead to Usher syndrome 1B which is characterized by deafness, reduced vestibular function, and retinal degeneration.

evidence.dc:description: clinical exome-targeted sequencing
evidence.rdfs:label: Family ATX-33

member.rdfs:label: Family ATX-33 Patient 42
member.previousTestingDescription: Common trinucleotide dynamic expansions in ATXN1 (SCA1), ATXN2 (SCA2), ATXN3 (SCA3), CACNA1A (SCA6), ATXN7 (SCA7), ATXN8 (SCA8), PPP2R2B (SCA12), TBP (SCA17), ATN1 (DRPLA), and FXN (Friedreich ataxia) were previously ruled out in all patients by PCR, followed by capillary electrophoresis. In addition, mutations in specific genes (FMR1 and RFC1) were studied in patients with a highly suggestive phenotype. Sequencing Panel (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA) for Illumina (San Diego, CA), in which 184 genes involved in CA and related forms were studied

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Gly357Val, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=0.00002227 (1/44900 alleles) in the East Asian population with 0 homozygotes.
This in-frame deletion, Glu519del, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=0.00005848 (69/1179940 alleles) in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes.
This missense variant, Asp13His, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=0.00001611 (19/1179066 alleles) in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes.
This nonsense variant, Lys316Ter, in exon 9/14 is absent from gnomAD v4.1.0.

RT-PCR of CWF19L1 cDNA product shows decreased amount of the c.946A>T transcript compared with the c.37G>C transcript, which was not seen on DNA level, indicating this allele is degraded by nonsense-mediated mRNA decay.

evidence.rdfs:label: Nguyen Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Exome of the index patient was captured using an exome enrichment kit including the UTR regions
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: "slow learner"; mild weakness; slurred, monotonic, sometimes even staccato-like speech and, although she was cooperative, slow in her performance; status after surgical strabismus correction; mild hypotonia with unsteady stance; increase in unsteadiness over a period of 1 year; symmetric and normal reflexes; prominent fissures and prominent surrounding cisterns; slight aspecific enlargement of the ventricles; in cerebrospinal fluid, there was an increase detected in myelin basic protein (MBP): 1.2 μg/l (normal: 0.3–1.0 μg/l)
evidence.previousTestingDescription: MYO18B is unlikely to cause ARCA as variants in this gene are associated with lung cancer or linked to Klippel–Feil anomaly and myopathy 10 which were not present in this patient.

evidence.dc:description: This nonsense variant, Tyr202Ter in exon 6/14, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=0.00001607 in the remaining population with 0 homozygotes. Down-scored for consanguinity and homozygosity.

evidence.rdfs:label: Alvarez Patient 2
evidence.detectionMethod: Probands were investigated by whole exome sequencing requested by the treating physician while the segregation studies were performed using Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Mild ID, severe speech delay, ataxia affecting gross and fine motor skills. Communicates using short sentences and sign language. He is able to walk short distances independently and uses a wheelchair for longer distances. Generalized intermittent slowing and focal sharp waves at the temporo-occipital lobe on EEG. Brain MRI showed cerebellar atrophy and periventricular T2-hyperintensities.

evidence.dc:description: This splice donor variant, c.964+1G>A, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=0.0007186 (46/64012 alleles) in the European (Finnish) population with 0 homozygotes. Down-scored for incomplete NMD (3 points) and consanguinity (0.5 points)

RT-PCR analysis of patient cells suggested that the mutation also caused nonsense-mediated mRNA decay, and Western blot analysis showed no evidence for the presence of the normal or predicted truncated protein, consistent with a loss of function.

evidence.rdfs:label: Yapici Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: WES filtered by homozygosity. Homozygosity mapping identified 13 regions >500 kb, spanning 71 Mb, approximately 2% of the genome, as homozygous and shared between the siblings, reaching LOD (logarithm of the odds) scores of 1.0 to 1.8 (see figure 1A for chromosome 10).
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The homozygosity regions contained 485 candidate genes, but no previously known ataxia genes. Of the 3 candidate gene mutations, 2 were unlikely to cause ataxia: a missense mutation in CDC73, as other mutations in this gene cause hyperparathyroidism, jaw syndromes, and cancer, and a missense mutation in GSTO1, as mutations in GSTO1 in humans and loss of GSTO1 in mice and drosophila does not cause any discernible phenotype.

evidence.dc:description: This canonical splice site variant, 708+1G>A, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=0.000 in the total population with 0 homozygotes. Down-scored for consanguinity and homozygosity.

evidence.rdfs:label: Alvarez Patient 3
evidence.detectionMethod: Probands were investigated by whole exome sequencing requested by the treating physician while the segregation studies were performed using Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Development remained normal before developing seizures at the age of 2 years with focal tonic seizure, bilateral clonic and focal to bilateral tonic clonic seizures. EEG showed epileptiform discharges over the right central region associated with eyelid myoclonus. The EEG also showed epileptiform discharges over central regions which was associated with bilateral clonic movements. At the age 13 years the EEG showed multifocal epileptiform discharges, with bilateral frontal and central right predominance. Brain MRI performed at the age of 5 years showed a hypoplastic corpus callosum and reduced volume of the right cerebellar hemisphere and vermis. Additional brain MRI at 12 years showed progressive cerebellar atrophy. Hypopigmentation in right thigh

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Ile151Ser, is absent in gnomAD v4.1.0. Down-scored for consanguinity and homozygosity

evidence.rdfs:label: Phulpagar Family 2 Patient 2
evidence.detectionMethod: Exome sequencing with Sanger sequencing for validation
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Slurred speech, tremulousness of bilateral upper limbs, and walking difficulty of one year duration. Intention tremor in upper limbs with mild incoordination in all four limbs (ICARS-25). MRI Brain showed atrophy of the cerebellum, pons, and middle cerebellar peduncles. At 23y, minimal progression of ataxia (ICARS-28), MRI brain showed severe cerebellar atrophy

evidence.dc:description: This canonical splice site variant, c.24-1G>C, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=0.00002120 (25/1179002 alleles) in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes. This variant was down-scored due to consanguinity and homozygosity
This canonical splice site variant, c.24-1G>C, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a MAF=0.00002120 (25/1179002 alleles) in the European NF population with 0 homozygotes. Down-scored for homozygosity
This missense variant, Asp132Gly, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=0.00001062 in the African/African American population with 0 homozygotes.

evidence.rdfs:label: Algahtani Proband (IV-3)
evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger sequencing was used to confirm the variant in other family members
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Previously healthy, but had imbalance, difficulty with mobilization and bilateral hand tremors at 30yo. Dropped from school at 15yo due to difficulty and failing exams, seizures at 20yo that went away with treatment of lamotrigine. Progression of phenotype over following months/years to include cerebellar dysarthria, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, horizontal and down-beat nystagmus, wide-based ataxic gait, inability to perform tandem gait, bilateral action tremors, brisk reflexes bilaterally with down-going toes, IQ in lower range of normal, cerebellar and vermis atrophy on MRI. SARA score=17/40

evidence.dc:description: This missense variant, Ala465Val, is absent in gnomAD v4.1.0.
This frameshift variant, Ser274fs in exon 8/14, is present in gnomAD v4.1.0 with a Grpmax FAF=0.0002058 in the East Asian population with 0 homozygotes.

evidence.rdfs:label: Alvarez Patient 4
evidence.detectionMethod: Probands were investigated by whole exome sequencing requested by the treating physician while the segregation studies were performed using Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Motor apraxia, mild ID (IQ of 63) at 5yo, progressive movement disorder with segmental myoclonus. Currently walks short distances with support but otherwise requires a wheelchair. He speaks though with significant dysarthria, but is unable to read or write. At the age of 15 years, he had a tonic–clonic seizure of unknown onset. EEG at 18 years showed epileptiform discharges frontally in the midline. Brain MRI performed at 18 years showed symmetric T2 signal elevation in the basal ganglia, atrophy of the caudate bilaterally and reduced volume of the cerebellar hemispheres.

evidence.dc:description: This splice site variant, c.1375-2A>G, is absent in gnomAD v4.1.0. Down-scored for alternative splicing, homozygosity, and consanguinity

Transcript analysis of the splice site variant revealed activation of a novel cryptic splice acceptor site on exon 13 resulting in an alternative transcription with a loss of nine nucleotides on exon 13. Translation of this transcript predicted an in-frame deletion of three amino acids p.(459_461del). The authors also observed a novel exon 13 skipping which results in premature termination of the protein product.

evidence.rdfs:label: Phulpagar Family 1 Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: Exome sequencing with Sanger sequencing for validation
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: seizures (generalized tonic clonic seizures). could hold his neck and sit with support, speak a few bi-syllables, recognize parents, and could track visual and auditory stimuli. He obeyed simple commands, could track visual and auditory stimulus. bilateral extensor plantar response with preserved power and sensation were noted in all four limbs. Cerebellar examination revealed appendicular dysmetria, intention tremor in upper limbs, and gait imbalance when made to walk with support. MRI showed altered T2/FLAIR intensity in the midbrain, pons, and middle cerebellar peduncles (Fig. 1B, C).
